title.narrative: Strengthening institutional effectiveness of JLOS through capacity building of senior and middle management

description.narrative:
**Long-term impact SRoL:**
- Rule of Law strengthened - Peace processes & political governance strengthened
**Long-term indicators:**
- 18 JLOS institutions are better able to perform their tasks independently, fairly, effectively, accountably and in better coordination - Number of citizens from all groups with increased awareness of rights and use of fair and effective formal and informal justice systems has increased with 5% - At least 4 initiatives established and implemented by JLOS institutions to support inclusive and accountable national and local governance
**Medium-term indicators:**
1. Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable 2. Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce
**Outcome at project level: **B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations in line with country / regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness (in partner countries and in the NL

The Center for International Legal Cooperation (CILC) and the Law Development Centre (LDC) are collaborating to strengthen the capacity of senior and middle management of JLOS affiliated institutions. The training is focused around results-oriented management, change management and leadership skills including the provision of guidance for clear budgeting, reporting and internal monitoring and evaluation. Emphasis is laid on enhancing human resource capacity and professionalism of the institutions which is crucial for improving service delivery and access to justice, especially for the vulnerable people. Thus, contributing to strengthening peace, justice and strong institutions (Sustainable Development Goals 16) in Uganda.
In this project we gear our support to strengthen skills of individual staff, institutions they work for and JLOS secretariat aiming at creating a wider impact through dissemination.
The LDC is a member of the Justice and Order Sector (JLOS), it holds strong ties with the JLOS Secretariat in the administration of justice. It is the only training institution within JLOS that is accredited to deliver professional training. So, this makes LDC a natural partner to deliver a sustainable management skill training for professionals in the JLOS on a permanent basis once this project has been realised.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Change agents training for Uganda JLOS
Project cycle management training for Uganda JLOS
Senior management training for Uganda JLOS
Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative:
In this section (maximum 1000 words), please
**For TMT+:**
Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: SROL.1 Human Security: Reduced levels of violence and levels of fear experienced
SROL.1.6. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) from marginalised groups who report on reduced levels of violence and fear experienced
SROL.1.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report a reduction in violent incidents in the area where they live
SROL.1.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report they are feeling secure in the area where they live
SROL.1.3. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report increased levels of trust in security sector actors
SROL.1.4. Number of beneficiaries who report having received positive service provision by formal and informal authorities with regard to human security
SROL.1.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report that they have a more negative perception about violent extremist organisations
SROL.1.10. Number of national/local authorities supported in addressing root causes and triggers of violent extremism, particularly through SRoL (push factors)
SROL.1.7. Number of policy influencing initiatives aimed at long-term stabilisation

SROL.1.8. Number of beneficiaries with relevant knowledge and skills to support the formal security sector to strengthen reform processes that ensure increased accountability, transparency and gendersensitivity
SROL.1.9. Number of community-based security sector providers that have improved knowledge and skills to offer effective, accountable and responsive service to citizens and government
SROL.2 Rule of Law Strengthened: Citizens are better able to access their rights through fair, efficient, impartial, independent and accountable institutions
SROL.2.3. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who access transitional justice mechanisms
SROL.2.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) with access to justice [note: this is an official DGIS-indicator] (separate out: no. of women who present cases of sexual violence or domestic abuse)
SROL.2.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who have improved awareness of their rights and/or of how to address justice problems (claim, defend, and or recover rights)
SROL.2.4. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who have improved awareness of their rights
SROL.2.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) from marginalised groups who have improved access to their rights and judicial service facilities.
SROL.2.6. Number of beneficiaries with increased capacity to support policies that promote increase to access to justice

SROL.2.7. Number of beneficiaries with increased capacity to provide (policy) advice on specialised topics such as informal justice, commercial justice, rehabilitation, juvenile justice, sharia, gender issues
SROL.2.8. Number of justice innovations (e.g. scenario planning)
SROL.3 Peace processes & political governance: States, regional and local authorities and societies at large are able to effectively prevent and resolve conflict in a non-violent and inclusive manner
SROL.3.1. Number conflicts that are addressed and resolved by community structures by the programme (note: this is an ARC indicator)
SROL.3.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel that community grievances of targeted groups (e.g. women, youth or a specific ethnic group) are effectively addressed (note: this is an ARC indicator)
SROL.3.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel represented by the government structures
SROL.3.6. Number of national and/or local level conflict resolution and peacebuilding mechanisms supported
SROL.3.7. Number of beneficiaries with increased knowledge and skills to support policy influencing of incountry and regional conflict resolution and peacebuilding interventions

SROL.3.8. Number of beneficiaries with increased knowledge and skills to support interventions at national level to increase civil society engagement and at local level to increase community engagement in political decision-making
SROL.3.9. Number of beneficiaries with improved capacity for policy influencing on aspects of political governance and state building
SROL.3.3. Participation (and satisfaction) in governance processes (political decision-making, mediation and dialogue) by representation of various groups, with special reference to women and youth
SROL.3.4. Perception on accountability/transparency of governance structures
SROL.4 Social and economic reconstruction: Income generating and livelihoods opportunities to prevent the (re)occurrence of conflicts, instability or irregular migration
SROL.4.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel represented by the government structures
SROL.4.2. (disaggregated) Number of programme beneficiaries who started a business / self-employment activity and sustained it 6 months after they started

SROL.4.3. (disaggregated) Number of programme beneficiaries who indicate that their business / self-employment activities (which existed already before the grantees' interventions) have grown over the last 6 months
SROL.4.4. (disaggregated) Number of trained/supported programme beneficiaries who have become employed
SROL.4.5. (disaggregated) Number of direct jobs supported by targeted companies
SROL.4.6. (disaggregated) Number of communities in programme areas that have adopted and are implementing livelihood protection strategies
SROL.4.10. Number of people supported to improve their income/ livelihood opportunities
SROL.4.7. Number of people with improved income in fragile and conflict-affected states
SROL.4.8. Number of people using new or improved water points in fragile and conflict-affected states
SROL.4.9. Number of direct jobs supported
B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction
B.I.3. % of scholarship holders / TMT participants / alumni employed post-study within region and same employer
B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women
B.I.5. % of scholarships awarded to minorities
B.I.9. % alumni / TMT participants who are promoted to a more strategic position post-study
B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training
B.O.3. Number of organisations with institutional mechanism for quality assurance
B.O.4. Number of organisations developed and implemented a gender strategy
B.I.7. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of minorities
B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates
B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication
B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment
B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)
B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace
III. Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce
III.I.2. % of alumni promoted to more strategic positions within their own organisation or other organisation
III.O.5. % of alumni who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment
III.I.1. % of alumni who state that they have applied in their workplace the knowledge and skills gained from the interventions
III.O.3. % employers that states that their department/organisation has become more effective because of OKP intervention
III.O.1. % employer satisfaction on suitability of the training for the organisation
III.O.2. % of alumni still employed by the organisation that nominated them
III.I.3. Narratives from alumni on policy and procedural changes, inclusive development, and innovations as a result of interventions
III.O.4. Testimonials from employers on organisational changes (implemented procedure/techniques, work ethic etc.) due to trained staff (critical mass)
II. Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable
II.P.2. Number of joint (research) proposals submitted and financed
II.P.3. Number of joint publications
II.P.4. Number of joint/double degrees offered
II.P.6. Number of scholarship holders that became members of the alumni association of their host university (of applied sciences)
II.P.8. Number of staff of Dutch training education organisations that have gained new insights and ways of working
II.P.5. Number of academic staff of partner country still cooperates with academic staff of other education organisation(s)
II.P.7. Number of Dutch training education organisations that have improved their training methods
